name: Lizzard Canyon
description:
Introduction

Fun, easy access/exit, very scenic, mostly beginner friendly, technical canyon in the CNM

Approach

First we left a shuttle vehicle on Mirador CT., it is an empty street about a quarter mile east of the west entrance to the Monument on the South side of Broadway. This will also be the exit of Lizzard Canyon.

Edit by Scott Patterson: To avoid trespassing, I'd recommend parking at Lower Monument Trailhead instead. It's only a little longer hike, but is all on public land. You don't have to climb the fence either and is on a trail.

Enter the Colorado National Monument from the West entrance (fee required or NP pass) and drive up to the campground entrance. If you're at the visitor center you have gone up to far. There is parking right by the entrance or we parked (room for 1 vehicle) on loop A by the bathroom (closest point to the hike to the canyon). From the loop A bathroom look N to NE for a power pole with powerlines. Hiking to the power pole will show you the canyon entrance. About a 15 minute hike.

Descent

The first rap is 190' that descends down a couple of terraces that we anchored off of a tree with a fiddlestick to avoid rope scars, a noticeable anchor, and to avoid camper temptation to descend and get hurt. (Edit: There is now a sling anchor not far right of the fall). Once in the canyon proper there are plenty of choices for anchors and we left webbing and rapide on a couple. The second rap was 115' two terrace with a great platform in the middle, 3rd rap was 90' with a great platform and the fourth rap was 140' off a tree up on the bench canyon left used to avoid a tricky pull (rope lengths are estimates). The last rappel also has a slung tree anchor on the bench canyon right.

Exit

Once past the rappels head down the canyon wash about a quarter mile then head cross country ENE looking for the shuttle vehicle left on Mirador Ct. which will be about a 25 minute hike total from the last rappel. You will have to cross a fence.

Edit by Scott Patterson: Once the canyon opens up, you can look for a trail to the right. This takes you to the Wedding Canyon Trail and the Lower Monument Canyon Trailhead. There is a trail, no fence to climb, and no trespassing.

Shuttle back up to retrieve your first vehicle

Red tape

Beta sites

Trip reports and media

Background

First descent by Scott Bordon, Nathan Dehart, Kyle Fullerton, Stephen Fullerton, Kelsey Ross, and Joe Uberhausen 4/29/2017
